title: Languages of Valoran
body:
Does anyone know if Ionian, Vastayan, etc., are actually full constructed languages being worked on by Riot, with actual comprehensive rules on grammar, syntax and the like (or at least fully developed naming languages)? Or are they making up the few fragments found here and there as they need them?

I'm asking because, if Riot has no intention on actually creating these languages, I'd like to try my hand at conlanging based on what we have so far, eventually.

replies.body: I'm pretty sure the narrative team has at least one language nerd who does something like this. I don't know if they're going to flesh these languages out at some point, though, like they did with Buhru (Illaoi's language ofc). (I forget which Rioter posted a little Buhru glossary...)

It was Odin/WAAARGHbobo.
https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/OPkqt6tg-waaarghbobo-you-say-you-work-on-champion-languages?comment=00000001000000000000

Any chance we'll see something similar for ancient Ionian? Karma's Mantra quotes and Yasuo's "Hasagi!" & "So ye gue dong!" are probably some of the most recognizable character lines in the game. It would be cool to hear more about that language.

> [{quoted}](name=Ultîma,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=KzmxHLtH,comment-id=000000000001,timestamp=2018-04-27T04:04:41.096+0000)
>
> Any chance we'll see something similar for ancient Ionian? Karma's Mantra quotes and Yasuo's "Hasagi!" & "So ye gue dong!" are probably some of the most recognizable character lines in the game. It would be cool to hear more about that language.

It's a little confusing though. Sounds to me Like Yasuo speaks a language that's the bastard child of Chinese and Korean, which then had a child with Japanese. Karma's Mantra quotes, however, sound more like a variant of Hindi. If they do expound upon these, I hope they tell us where each language is spoken and how both ended up in the Ionian vernacular.

I've shared those thoughts too, and my main take-away is that Karma's Mantra quotes are ancient Ionian, whereas Yasuo's quotes are in the modern Ionian tongue. Although after reading Riven's story I'm not so sure anymore. One of my key issues regarding the linguistics of Ionian is that we still don't really have a map of Ionia itself - is it a country or a continent? I'd find the differences in dialects a bit tougher to swallow if Ionia happens to be only the size of Demacia, for example.

Excellent question. I could absolutely see it being a sort of Australia, where it's a country as well as a continent. There's precedent for cultural divisions already, with the Vastaya, so it's very possible they'll say Ionia is a continent that's come under the unified rule of an Ionian government, and there are different sub-cultures within that have different original tongues.

Any chance you could have him post that again, using notation from the International Phonetic Alphabet? I have no clue what he meant by any of his pronunciation guidelines, if the apostrophes have any phonetic significance (like the Hawaiian _ʻokina_), etc. It also doesn't answer my question about grammar, or how thoroughly you work out your languages in general.
